column2: Description
Level 1 corrective drill. Uses the wall to offload bodyweight and guide the vertical spine position. Ideal for athletes with FMS Score 1 who cannot maintain balance in a deep squat.
Level 2 progression. Introduces a single-leg bias while maintaining wall support. Use to identify and correct left/right imbalances in the squat pattern before removing support.
Level 3 activation drill. Adds RNT (Reactive Neuromuscular Training) to pull the athlete into the mistake
column3: forcing them to engage the core and glutes to resist. Excellent for "feeding the dysfunction."

column2: Level 4 mobility/stability hybrid. The Figure-4 position challenges hip mobility while the wall ensures safety. Use for athletes needing hip opening combined with pattern work.
Level 5 strength-endurance. Adds external load to the static wall hold. Builds quad capacity and trunk stiffness without the complexity of a free-standing squat.
Level 6 advanced stability. The Zercher position (bar in elbows) forces high anterior core engagement. Excellent for athletes who dump forward in their squat pattern.
Level 7 smoothness drill. The ball reduces friction
column3: allowing for a fluid descent. Good for patterning specific depth control before moving to barbell squats.

column2: Level 1 regression. The band provides lift at the bottom (sticking point)
column3: allowing athletes to experience full range of motion without full gravity load. Best for those with weakness at depth.

column2: Level 2 assisted pattern. Uses suspension straps to allow the athlete to "sit back" further than normal
column3: deloading the knees and emphasizing hip hinge mechanics.

column2: Level 3 tactile cueing. A partner provides specific resistance or assistance. useful for coaching precise torso angles and knee tracking in real-time.
Level 4 transition drill. Using a fixed bar for balance allows the athlete to self-correct stability issues while bearing mostly their own weight.
Level 1 mobility bypass. Elevating the heels removes ankle mobility restrictions. Combined with band assistance
column3: this is the safest regression for stiff athletes.

column2: Level 2 patterning. Removes ankle stiffness variable while using the wall for posture. Isolate hip mechanics without fighting ankle restrictions.
Level 3 standard regression. The "Cyclist Squat" position. Allows for a purely vertical torso and deep knee flexion. Diagnostic tool: If they can squat here but not flat
column3: the issue is ankles.

column2: Level 4 loaded regression. Adds anterior load to the heel-raised position. The counterbalance of the weight often cleans up the squat pattern instantly.
Level 5 rhythm drill. Continuous tension squats with elevated heels. Builds vastus medialis strength and knee resilience under control.
Level 6 strength progression. Loading the heel-elevated pattern with dumbbells. Bridges the gap between corrective mobility work and real strength training.
Level 1 baseline pattern. The Prisoner position (hands behind head) forces thoracic extension
column3: preventing the athlete from rounding the upper back.

column2: Level 2 mobility drill. Starting from a deep hip hinge/stretch position and dropping into the squat. Excellent for mobilizing the hips dynamically.
Level 3 flow/endurance. A high-rep bodyweight movement involving heel elevation and arm swings. Builds coordination and joint flushing.
Level 4 mobility challenge. Facing the wall to force an upright torso. If the athlete leans forward
column3: they hit the wall. The ultimate self-limiting drill for upright posture.

column2: Level 5 stability bias. One foot slightly forward shifts the center of mass. A regression from single-leg squats that builds independent leg strength.
Level 6 mobility challenge. Feet together demands higher ankle mobility and balance. Use to refine the midline stability of the squat.
Level 7 advanced mobility. A gymnastics-style squat requiring extreme core compression and mobility. Only for athletes with FMS Score 3.
Level 10 isolation. Extreme knee flexion and quad isolation. Not a functional pattern but a high-performance accessory for knee tendon health.
Level 1 hip pattern. Wide stance biases the adductors and allows for a more upright torso. Use for athletes with long femurs who struggle with conventional stance.
Level 2 RNT drill. Bands around knees force the athlete to drive knees out (abduction)
column3: engaging the glute medius during the wide stance.

column2: Level 3 loaded patterning. The wide base provides high stability
column3: allowing the athlete to focus purely on the hip hinge mechanics.

column2: Level 4 strength. Dumbbell variation allows for independent hand positioning
column3: challenging grip and symmetry.

column2: Level 5 strength. Barbell loading increases systemic demand. The "Hang" position keeps the weight center of mass low
column3: aiding balance.

column2: Level 6 anterior core. Holding a plate out front acts as a counterbalance
column3: forcing the core to brace against the long lever arm.

column2: Level 7 anti-flexion. The Zercher carry forces the athlete to fight against collapsing forward
column3: building massive upper back strength.

column2: Level 8 multi-planar. An asymmetrical barbell lift that challenges rotation and anti-rotation stability.
Level 1 depth control. The box provides a tactile target
column3: ensuring consistent depth and safety. Removes the stretch reflex

column2: Level 2 asymmetry check. Single leg box squat. limits the range of motion to a safe height while building unilateral strength.
Level 3 mobility range. Using a lower box to progressively increase the depth demand as mobility improves.
Level 4 loaded control. Adding load to the box pattern. Teaches the athlete to absorb force quietly on the box rather than crashing down.
Level 5 independent loading. Using dumbbells adds a stability component to the fixed range of motion of the box.
Level 6 maximal strength. The classic powerlifting builder. Allows for supramaximal loads at partial ranges to build confidence and neural drive.
Level 7 overhead stability. Combining the box depth check with the overhead position to ruthlessly audit thoracic and shoulder mobility.
Level 1 foundational strength. The "King of Corrections." The anterior load counterbalances the athlete
column3: allowing them to sit deeper with better posture.

column2: Level 2 grip/stability. Holding the KB upside down (bottoms up) demands intense grip and shoulder stability
column3: radiating tension to the core.

column2: Level 3 classic loading. The standard for building squat volume safely. Self-limiting: if the upper back rounds
column3: the weight drops.

column2: Level 4 lateral bias. Holding the weight to one side (offset) forces the obliques to fight rotation.
Level 2 front load. Double kettlebells in the rack position compress the chest
column3: forcing high respiratory demand and thoracic extension.

column2: Level 3 offset load. One KB racked. The unequal load tries to pull the athlete sideways; the core must fight to stay vertical.
Level 4 anti-lateral flexion. Holding weights at sides (like suitcases). If the core is weak
column3: the weights hit the floor.

column2: Level 8 conditioning. Continuous tension reps with Kettlebells. High metabolic demand for conditioning phases.
Level 3 independent stability. Dumbbells in the rack position require more shoulder stability than a barbell but less wrist flexibility.
Level 9 advanced mobility. Stabilizing independent dumbbells overhead requires perfect shoulder symmetry and core lock-in.
Level 10 maximal power. The gold standard for lower body force production. Only for athletes who have cleared all mobility and stability checks.
Level 10 postural strength. Anterior loading forces an upright torso. Directly transfers to olympic lifting and athletic jumping mechanics.
Level 1 regression. Split stance with upper body support. Removes balance as a limiting factor to focus on hip separation.
Level 2 baseline stability. Static lunge pattern. The foundation of all single-leg athletic movement.
Level 4 strength/mobility. "Bulgarian Split Squat." Places extreme stretch on the rear hip flexor while overloading the front leg.
Level 5 loaded stability. Adding load to the split stance. Builds pelvic stability and knee tracking integrity.
Level 7 unstable load. The shifting sand forces micro-adjustments in the core and hips.
Level 8 guided arc. The fixed arc of the bar provides stability while allowing heavy loading in a unilateral pattern.
Level 2 dynamic control. Moving from a stable base to a dynamic step and back. Challenges deceleration mechanics.
Level 3 friction control. Using a slider removes the impact of the step but increases the eccentric demand on the muscles.
Level 7 dynamic strength. Continuous forward movement. Demands dynamic stability and coordination in space.
Level 9 loaded arc. Combining the dynamic step of a lunge with the unique leverage of the Landmine.
Level 1 RNT. The band pulls the athlete forward
column3: forcing them to engage the posterior chain to stay upright.

column2: Level 7 starting strength. Starting from a dead stop on pins at the bottom. Eliminates the stretch reflex to build pure starting power.
Level 3 safety overload. Using a safety bar and holding the rack handles. Allows for massive overloading of the legs with reduced back strain.
Level 3 frontal plane. Moving side-to-side. Critical for preventing groin injuries and building athletic agility.
Level 10 mastery. Single leg
column3: unsupported
column4: full depth. The ultimate display of combined mobility
